articles.headline: A Loophole Lets a Foot in the Door
articles.snippet: How to accumulate enormous stakes in a company without tipping your hand.
articles.abstract: How to accumulate enormous stakes in a company without tipping your hand.
articles.lead_paragraph: The bad news reached Neil Ashe, the chief executive of CNet, as he lounged on the beach in Mexico on vacation with his family over the holidays. The company’s lawyer called to say that two hedge funds had secretly acquired the equivalent of a 21 percent stake in CNet and planned to mount a proxy contest to take over the board.

articles.headline: Citi to Announce Big Cuts and New Investors
articles.snippet: Citigroup is expected to announce on Tuesday 4,000 additional job cuts, a steep cut in its stock dividend, and another boost from foreign investors.
articles.abstract: Citigroup is expected to announce on Tuesday 4,000 additional job cuts, a steep cut in its stock dividend, and another boost from foreign investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Citigroup is expected to announce a series of drastic steps on Tuesday, including the elimination at least 4,000 additional jobs, a steep cut in its stock dividend and another big investment by foreign investors, in a bid to bolster its finances in the face of deepening losses.

articles.headline: In Obama’s Pursuit of Latinos, Race Plays Role
articles.snippet: Barack Obama confronts a history of often uneasy and competitive relations between blacks and Latinos.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama confronts a history of often uneasy and competitive relations between blacks and Latinos.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has eaten beef tacos in East Los Angeles and sat on the living room couch of a working-class family in a largely Hispanic neighborhood here for 30 televised minutes. At a rally of the culinary workers’ union in the shadows of the Strip here one night, Senator Barack Obama pumped his fist and chanted with the crowd, “¡Sí, se puede; sí, se puede; sí, se puede!” or, “Yes, we can!”
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jennifer Steinhauer

articles.headline: Europe May Ban Imports of Some Biofuel Crops
articles.snippet: If approved, the law would prohibit the importation of fuels derived from crops grown on certain kinds of land — including forests, wetlands or grasslands.
articles.abstract: If approved, the law would prohibit the importation of fuels derived from crops grown on certain kinds of land — including forests, wetlands or grasslands.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  In a sign of growing concern about the impact of supposedly “green” policies, European Union officials will propose a ban on imports of certain biofuels, according to a draft law to be unveiled next week.

articles.headline: Study Reveals Doubt on Drug for Cholesterol
articles.snippet: A clinical trial of Zetia, a widely used cholesterol drug, has raised questions about its effectiveness and the behavior of pharmaceutical companies that conducted the study.
articles.abstract: A clinical trial of Zetia, a widely used cholesterol drug, has raised questions about its effectiveness and the behavior of pharmaceutical companies that conducted the study.
articles.lead_paragraph: A clinical trial of a widely used cholesterol drug has raised questions both about the medicine’s effectiveness and about the behavior of the pharmaceutical companies that conducted the study, cardiologists said Monday.

articles.headline: Foreign Sales Help I.B.M. to a Strong Quarter
articles.snippet: The technology giant’s quarterly profit — up 24 percent — may not be as reliable an indicator of broader trends in the American economy as in the past.
articles.abstract: The technology giant’s quarterly profit — up 24 percent — may not be as reliable an indicator of broader trends in the American economy as in the past.
articles.lead_paragraph: A slowing American economy is not hurting I.B.M. yet.

articles.headline: Chinese and U.S. Demand Drives Commodities Surge
articles.snippet: A global boom in the cost of commodities, the staple ingredients of a modern economy, is entering its sixth year with no end in sight.
articles.abstract: A global boom in the cost of commodities, the staple ingredients of a modern economy, is entering its sixth year with no end in sight.
articles.lead_paragraph: The price of copper has tripled in five years. Zinc has doubled. Wheat and soybeans rose 70 percent in 2007. Futures prices of crude oil, gold, silver, lead, uranium, cattle, cocoa and corn are all at or near records.

articles.headline: Europe’s Appetite for Seafood Propels Illegal Trade
articles.snippet: Europe’s dinner tables are increasingly supplied by global fishing fleets, which are depleting the world’s oceans.
articles.abstract: Europe’s dinner tables are increasingly supplied by global fishing fleets, which are depleting the world’s oceans.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  Walking at the Brixton market among the parrotfish, doctorfish and butterfish, Effa Edusie is surrounded by pieces of her childhood in Ghana. Caught the day before far off the coast of West Africa, they have been airfreighted to London for dinner.

articles.headline: Baltimore Finds Subprime Crisis Snags Women
articles.snippet: The subprime mortgages that are driving the foreclosure rate have gone disproportionately to women.
articles.abstract: The subprime mortgages that are driving the foreclosure rate have gone disproportionately to women.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE  At Vixxen Hair Salon, the main topic of conversation has always been money. But since last August, Anjanette Booker, the owner, has noticed a new focus. “Now it’s money and foreclosures,” Miss Booker said.

articles.headline: Militants Escape Control of Pakistan, Officials Say
articles.snippet: Pakistan’s premier military intelligence agency has lost control of some of the Pakistani militants it has nurtured.
articles.abstract: Pakistan’s premier military intelligence agency has lost control of some of the Pakistani militants it has nurtured.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistan’s premier military intelligence agency has lost control of some of the networks of Pakistani militants it has nurtured since the 1980s, and is now suffering the violent blowback of that policy, two former senior intelligence officials and other officials close to the agency say.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and David Rohde

articles.headline: Minister Sees Need for U.S. Help in Iraq Until 2018
articles.snippet: The Iraqi defense minister said that Iraq would not be able to take full responsibility for its security until 2018.
articles.abstract: The Iraqi defense minister said that Iraq would not be able to take full responsibility for its security until 2018.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT MONROE, Va.  The Iraqi defense minister said Monday that his nation would not be able to take full responsibility for its internal security until 2012, nor be able on its own to defend Iraq’s borders from external threat until at least 2018.
